commentary.line: That brings us to the end of our coverage of the Test series between West Indies and England. Hope you enjoyed following it here. Until next time, this is Sidhant Maheshwari, signing off on behalf of Krishna and Kaushik.

Cook: 'We came here after Grenada and we had the opportunity to make it 2-0. We did well for the first day and a half. It's a bit of both, 250 wasn't enough in the first innings, probably 300 was par, and then obviously 120 was disappointing. It was a good toss to win. This loss is a tough one to take. Full credit to West Indies for bowling that well and that chase on that pitch was also a great one. When you're defending 190 odd, you need to take every chance, but we didn't do it. Every series we play we want to win, so that is a failure that way. I can't fault the effort from the lads but we were not good enough in the last 20 overs. We weren't good enough to win this Test match. We will take it on the chin. The squad will stay together and for the majority of the series, we did really well but we didn't quite do it well enough.'
England retain the Wisden Trophy as the series ended 1-1

Ramdin: 'It was a very tricky one, but it turned out well for us. We lost the toss but the bowlers came out so well for us in this game. The batsmen didn't quite do as well as we wanted in the first innings but young Bravo and Blackwood came out for us today and batted brilliantly. Taylor and the others did extremely well. We knew that we needed to take those early wickets that time and the bowlers did extremely well to take five wickets yesterday. Both teams have played some good cricket. We knew we could beat them and we have shown that today. The youngsters are extremely positive and they want to win. Hopefully, we can keep playing like this.'

Anderson: 'We played some good cricket throughout the series. We got the first innings lead here as well, but it didn't work out. We thought that we had a chance when we took a couple of wickets, but they chased it down well. I feel I have contributed to the team's success, but a little disappointed with the loss. For a few of us, it might be the last time we come here if we take another 6 years to come back to West Indies. The English crowd support has been great for us everywhere and we had a great time here.'
James Anderson is the Man of the Series for taking 17 wickets in the series

Blackwood: 'I always try to play my natural game, but it's a different situation everytime I bat. You have to bat according to the situation. I always want to play my natural game and I don't get worried if I get out playing my natural game. It is important to mix my natural game with a bit of defence and it came out really well here. Bravo told me to stay positive and take it 10 runs at a time. With each Test series I am learning and that's a good thing for me.'
Jermaine Blackwood is the Man of the Match for scores of 85 and 47*
Time for the presentation ceremony

By virtue of their win, West Indies denied England an away series win, a feat that has eluded them since their historic win in India in late 2012. They now head to a grueling summer of Test cricket at home where they'll host New Zealand before welcoming the Aussies for the all-important Ashes. For a young West Indies side that was pummeled on its tour to South Africa, a result like this couldn't have come at a better time. Ramdin and Co. can take heart from this performance and build on it. For Cook and Moores though, it's back to the drawing board.
Match Recap:

Coming to the opening days of the Test, England had it all going their way to complete the series win. Alastair Cook broke a sequence of 35 Test innings without a ton with a patient 105 but besides a half-century from Moeen Ali, England failed to get sizable contributions from the rest and got just 257 in the first innings. Another virtuoso performance from James Anderson (6 for 42), his 17th five-wicket haul in Tests, helped them eke out a 68-run lead before West Indies capped off a memorable 18-wicket Day 2 by removing half of the English batting line-up for next to nothing. Taylor, Holder and Permaul then finished with three wickets apiece on the third morning as England folded for a paltry 123 in their second essay. On a track that offered enough assistance, defending a target of 192 still required a strong bowling performance from Anderson and company. Bravo and Blackwood though had other plans and their famous partnership helped West Indies cruise to a series-levelling win.
Day 3 summary:

In retrospect it was England who enjoyed a brighter start to Day 3. Resuming on their overnight lead of 107, they added 51 runs in the first hour before Permaul, Holder and Taylor conspired to trigger a collapse. Despite a flourish from Jos Buttler, England were bowled out for 123 in their second innings thereby setting a target of 192. West Indies had never lost a Test chasing under 200 and they set about the chase in a positive manner. Despite losing early wickets, Darren Bravo (82) and Jermaine Blackwood's (47*) match-winning stand helped the hosts seal a famous Test match win.
Session summary:

Bravo started the final session in emphatic fashion by hitting Joe Root for a six and a four before the lull set in. Chanderpaul played on to an Anderson loosener before Blackwood and Bravo showed immense caution against the English attack for the next half an hour. The duo complemented each other and batted extremely well as Alastair Cook kept ringing in changes. While Bravo was enticed occasionally into playing a false shot, his 23-year old partner remained largely nonplussed. Bravo registered his 11th Test fifty in typically wristy fashion and in the process completed the fifty run stand between the two. He was dismissed finally for a superb 82, just four runs short of the win but Blackwood remained unbeaten and took his side home.

Darren Bravo and Jermaine Blackwood sealed a remarkable turnaround for the West Indies with a series levelling 108-run stand as West Indies came back from conceding a 68-run first innings lead to record a 5-wicket win.

Blackwood is extremely delighted after hitting the winning runs. He punches the air in delight. Ramdin hugs him and the English players congratulate Blackwood and Ramdin. The West Indians also walk out to shake hands with the Englishmen.

62.4   Moeen Ali to Blackwood, FOUR, that's it! West Indies win by 5 wickets, a historic win for the men from the Caribbean. The series ends 1-1. England continue to chase an away series win in Tests. Coming back to the ball, it was floated up on the stumps, Blackwood comes down the track and lofts it over mid-on for a boundary

Denesh Ramdin, right handed bat, comes to the crease

61.6   Stokes to Darren Bravo, out Caught by Broad!! Bravo is livid with himself for throwing it away right before the end. Blackwood pats him on the back as he makes his way back to the pavilion. He waves his bat to the crowd, who continue to applaud his effort. Coming back to the ball, it was a low full toss outside off, Bravo wanted to go over mid-off but doesn't get the desired elevation. Broad moves to his right, jumps high and takes the catch. Darren Bravo c Broad b Stokes 82(148) [4s-7 6s-3]
Stokes to Darren Bravo, THATS OUT!! Caught!!

Just when it looked like Cook had allowed the game to drift, he's rung in key changes 20 minutes before tea and England finished the session with 37 consecutive dot balls. The Caribbeans need 122 runs more to win, with 7 wickets at their disposal. The final session promises to be exciting. Join us in just a bit for that.

West Indian openers, Hope and Brathwaite, survived the new ball burst from Anderson and Broad but soon fell in quick succession mainly due to the brilliance of Chris Jordan. Jordan first caught Hope plumb in front of the stumps before taking a superb reflex catch to send Brathwaite back. Samuels and Bravo then added 35 steady runs before Broad knocked over Samuels just before tea following a sequence of 22 dot balls.

A big appeal for lbw. Umpire Bowden says not out and Cook immediately went for the review. It looks very close, umpire Bowden gave it not out probably because he thought the impact was outside the line of off. The players are making their way out the middle. We will just have one over before lunch. Anderson will bowl it, he has three slips and a gully in place.

After Stokes fell, Buttler decided to take the attack to West Indies. With Jordan and Broad getting out on successive balls, Buttler added some quick runs with some lusty blows. In the end, Anderson's wicket brought the English innings to a close and now it is upto their bowlers to take these final 10 wickets to make it 2-0.

West Indies need 192 runs to win this match and level the series. We will probably have one over before lunch. On a pitch that continued to crumble, Ballance and Stokes added 23 runs before Ballance edged one to Bravo at slip, with Permaul picking up his second wicket of the innings. Stokes continued to play a few shots, especially the reverse sweep, while Buttler held the other end. Stokes though got out trying to hit one out of the park, with Chanderpaul taking a good low catch at cover.

Taylor and Ramdin though immediately decided to review and Hawk-Eye showed all three reds and Anderson's wicket brings an end to the English innings. J Anderson lbw b Jerome Taylor 2(11)

The West Indian players are standing in a circle with Curtly Ambrose having another animated chat with them. The English batters are making their way out to the middle. Taylor will start the proceedings from round the wicket on day 3. He has two slips and a gully in place.

Their current score is 39/5 and they effectively lead by 107 runs right now. Ballance and Stokes are currently at the crease and they will look to add as many runs as possible today. However, with the assistance on offer, the West Indian bowlers will look to take these final 5 wickets quickly today. So, who will come out on top? We will get to know in a short while from now. Stay tuned for the live action.

However, the final session proved to be a roller coaster of sorts. From England dominating the proceedings to West Indian bowlers coming back with a bang, this match is heading towards an exciting finish. Brilliant bit of swing bowling from the West Indian pacers saw England losing wickets in a heap. With Permaul picking up Ali's wicket, the Englishmen ended the day with half their side back in the hut.

Blackwood was the only batsman to make a fine contribution to the West Indian total. He top-scored with 85 and the second highest score from a West Indian was a distant 25 made by Shivnarine Chanderpaul. Anderson picked up 6/42, his 17th 5-wicket haul, helping England take a crucial 68-run lead in the first innings. It was upto their batsmen to build on the lead after the bowlers did their job.

Apart from Jermaine Blackwood, all the other batsmen found it tough to get going yesterday. England lost their final three wickets quickly and West Indies came out to bat, hoping to score big on a pitch that is deteriorating quickly. However, their hopes were quashed by the English bowlers as West Indies were bowled out for 189.
On behalf of Krishna and Kaushik, this is Sidhant Maheshwari, saying goodbye. See you tomorrow!

On a day in which 18 wickets fell, the most to have fallen on a single day in a Test match in West Indies, the hosts have sneaked ahead thanks to a remarkable comeback in the final session. Earlier in the day, England added only 17 runs to their overnight score of 240/7 as Jerome Taylor ran through the English tail. James Anderson then gave a fitting riposte and ended with figures of 6/42. Only Jermaine Blackwood (85) offered a substantial contribution as West Indies conceded a lead of 68. The first session of play on Day 3 will be crucial for both the teams. If Ben Stokes and Gary Ballance see the first hour through tomorrow morning, England can then take the game away from the hosts. Do join us tomorrow for what promises to be another enthralling day of Test cricket.

England's plans of pressing home the first innings advantage soon dissipated as Jerome Taylor and Shanon Gabriel produced a probing spell of pace bowling and quickly reduced England to 18/3. Taylor was particularly impressive and snared Trott and Bell with sharp inswingers. Holder added the key wicket of Joe Root and Moeen Ali played on a Permaul delivery to give West Indies momentum going into the third day. England however have a lead of 107 to build on.

James Anderson's 17th five-wicket haul meant England bowled West Indies out in just over two sessions and picked up a crucial 68-run first innings lead. West Indies' innings unravelled soon after tea when Anderson sent back Permaul and Taylor in quick succession. Blackwood struck a couple of meaty blows before becoming the last man to fall after making a valiant 85.

Cook and Trott are at the crease. Cook is on strike. Jerome Taylor will open the attack

The West Indian players are standing near the boundary rope, with Curtly Ambrose giving them the pep talk. Trott and Cook make their way out to the middle. Taylor will start the proceedings with the ball. There are two slips and a gully in place.

England currently lead by 68 runs and they will now look to build on this lead. On the other hand, West Indies know that they need to bowl well here as the pitch will offer more assistance to the bowlers in the fourth innings. Can the West Indian bowlers end the day on a high? Or will the English batsmen march on? We will find out in a short while. Stay tuned.

Anderson started off proceedings after tea and soon got the wicket of Permaul. Blackwood, on the other end, kept chipping away with boundaries. Taylor too hit a few lusty blows before Anderson sent him back to take his 17th 5-wicket haul in Test cricket. In the end, Blackwood decided to go after the bowling since he was running out of partners at the other end. After hitting Anderson for a six in the 50th over, he again tried to hit him out of the park but failed to connect that well, with Ali taking a good catch at the boundary to bring an end to the innings.

The players walk off with Anderson leading them off the field. He has the cherry in his hand as he makes his way back to the dressing room. He bowled 12.4 overs in this innings and picked up 6 wickets. Brilliant exhibition of swing bowling from him.

Welcome back. The players are making their way out the middle. Anderson will start the proceedings after tea. There are two slips in place for him.

The part-timer sent back veteran Chanderpaul with a tossed up delivery that invited the outside edge and Jordan at slip pulled off a blinder. Ramdin and Blackwood then batted cautiously to take the West Indies total past 100 before Broad had the West Indies skipper edge a full delivery in the channel outside off. With the ball reversing, Ben Stokes joined the party and added the wicket of Jason Holder. Jermaine Blackwood has scored an entertaining fifty but West Indies still trail by 118, with just 3 wickets remaining. How close can they get? Tune in for the final session in just a bit.

Wickets continued to tumble in the second session as England moved into the ascendancy. Darren Bravo lasted just 3 balls after lunch. Moeen Ali got one to turn and bounce of a length and the outside edge was snaffled by Jordan at slip. Despite the loss of early wickets,Chanderpaul and Blackwood batted positively, the latter taking Moeen for 14 in one particular over. With Ali taken apart, Cook resorted to bowling his other spinner, Joe Root.

Welcome back. The players are making their way out to the middle. Ali will start the proceedings after lunch. There is a slip and a gully in place. Here we go then...

Anderson then gave a demonstration of classic Test match fast bowling. He took just 2 balls to get Brathwaite out as he went for a duck at his home ground. Cook then dropped a sharp chance off Darren Bravo but held on to another catch off Anderson's bowling, sending the debutant Shai Hope back to the hut. Anderson picked his third wicket when he set up Marlon Samuels with a series of outswingers before getting one to shape back in and trap the right-hander plumb in front of the stumps. Chanderpaul and Bravo now have a lot of repair work to do in the post-lunch session. Join us for all the action in just over 30 minutes.

West Indies didn't take long to wrap up the England tail on day 2. Jerome Taylor and Shannon Gabriel opened proceedings with the second new ball on Day 2, after Samuels finished bowling his final four balls of the over from yesterday. Like on Day 1, Taylor struggled with consistency in his bowling lines early on in his spell. Many good deliveries were followed by ones drifting down the leg-side. Eventually, one such ball consumed Chris Jordan, who tickled it to the keeper. Gabriel and Taylor then peppered Stuart Broad with a barrage of short deliveries. England could only add 17 to their overnight score before Taylor knocked over Broad and Anderson off successive deliveries to finish the English innings for 257.

West Indies have done magnificently well to take the final three English wickets for just 17 runs. Taylor was the star of the show today as he picked up all the three wickets. If Jordan was strangled down the leg-side, Broad and Anderson were knocked over for pace. Buttler was stranded at the other end and couldn't do much. Now, it is upto the West Indian batsmen to seize the advantage. If they manage to post a big first innings total, West Indies will have a big chance of winning this game, with the pitch deteriorating. Live action is a few minutes

On the other hand, the English lower-order are no mugs with the bat. Jordan will now join Buttler at the crease and both of them will look to pile on as many runs as possible. For West Indies, the pacers have bowled well on occasions, but Permaul was very disappointing yesterday. Even though he managed to take the wicket of Root, he proved to be expensive as he gave away 86 runs in his 20 overs. Let's see if he can make some amends today.

Hello and welcome to day 2 of the final Test between West Indies and England. West Indies had the last laugh yesterday as they were able to take 7 English wickets. They'll now be hoping to take the final three wickets, bowling England out for a modest total. Considering that the pitch is already offering some turn, West Indies would ideally want to put up a big total in the first innings.

706 days since his 25th Test hundred, Alastair Cook reached a much-awaited landmark yesterday, his 26th Test ton. Cook was ecstatic after reaching his ton, but his happiness was short-lived as he soon got out, that too in the final over of the day. Cook's reaction after his fall though trumped his celebrations after his century as he stood his ground in disbelief momentarily.
Until tomorrow, this is Sidhant Maheshwari, signing off on behalf of Bhanu and Kaushik. See you tomorrow, folks!

Earlier in the day, Alastair Cook's decision of opting to bat first backfired when Jonathan Trott fell for a third-ball duck. Jason Holder then dispelled doubts about his fitness with two important wickets. First, he uprooted Gary Ballance's middle-stump and then induced an indeterminate prod from new batsman Ian Bell with a slower delivery to take a sharp catch off his own bowling. In-form batsman Joe Root and Cook added 53 for the fourth wicket before the former fell straight after lunch to Permaul. Cook and Ali then got together for a 98-run union, before Ali was run out as Cook went for a non-existent single. Alastair Cook's dismissal in the final over has given West Indies the edge at the end of Day 1. Can they drive home the advantage by bowling England out quickly on the second day? Join us tomorrow to find out.

In the final session, Denesh Ramdin inexplicably preferred to bowl his spinners in tandem and allowed Moeen Ali and Cook to milk the bowling by setting defensive fields. By the time Jerome Taylor returned to the attack, Ali had completed his half-century and was able to pick off the pacer's variations with ease. Cook handled Taylor's strategy of bowling full and wide outside off-stump with elan. The duo added 98 for the fifth wicket before a run-out ended Moeen's stay at the crease. Even after Moeen fell, Cook continued to battle away along with Ben Stokes and helped England cross the 200-run mark. Holder and Gabriel bowling with the second new ball toiled hard and the latter was rewarded for his persistence when Stokes played one away from his body and was caught at gully with just four overs left to play in the day. Samuels had Cook in the final over of the day to give West Indies the first day honours.

Alastair Cook battled his way to a Test century, his 26th. He reached the three-figure mark in Test cricket after a gap of 706 days. Playing with oodles of patience and assurance in shot-making, Cook helped England recover from a precarious 38/3 in the first session before falling in the final over of the day for 105 off 266 as West Indies finished the day on a high.

For a moment, Cook stood his ground in disbelief as West Indian players started celebrating. He walks off and soaks in the applause, waves his bat to the crowd. His team-mates too pat him on the back as he makes his way to the dressing room.

Welcome back. Cook is looking good for a century, but can West Indies stop him? We will find out in this session. The players are walking out to the middle. Samuels will start the proceedings with the ball. He will start from round the wicket. There is a slip and a gully in place

Shannon Gabriel was re-introduced into the attack soon after Cook got to his 50 and was duly pulled away for four. Moeen picked up a couple of boundaries off Holder and the pair motored along to their fifty partnership. Lead spinner, Permaul, despite getting rid of Root early in the session, continued to be expensive. With the pitch easing up for batting, England will want these two to carry on for the bulk of the final session to help post a competitive first innings total. Join us for the final session in just a bit.

West Indies struck early after lunch when Permaul had the well-set Joe Root caught behind for a brisk 33. With the half-century stand ended and the pitch offering some turn, Ramdin had Samuels bowl his off-spinners from the other end. Alastair Cook, in arguably his best form of the tour, maneuvered the field and helped himself to a crucial half-century off 139 balls. Moeen Ali survived a couple of nervy moments against the spinners before settling down against the medium-pace of Holder. Cook, on the other hand, looked largely untroubled. A hallmark of Cook's innings was the way he left the ball outside the off-stump.

Welcome back. The players are out in the centre. Permaul will start the proceedings after lunch. Root is on strike. There is a slip and a short leg in place.

With Gabriel taking the ball away from the left-handers and Taylor shaping it into them from around the wicket, Cook and Ballance remained content on playing them out sedately. The introduction of Marlon Samuels brought about a slight increase in the scoring rate before Ballance was knocked over by a sharp delivery from Holder. Holder made it two in two overs when he caught and bowled Ian Bell for a duck. In-form Joe Root started briskly and importantly Alastair Cook is still around and England will hope that he converts this start into a big one, having survived the crucial first session. Join us in a short while for the post-lunch session.

As Jeff Dujon pointed out - There are certain words you don't associate with the Kensington Oval - Dry and Flat. But that's what it was as an unchanged England side opted to bat first in Barbados. The visitors however, took an overly cautious approach to batting in the first session and ended up losing three wickets without adding too much. West Indies struck first when Shanon Gabriel sent back Jonathan Trott for the third duck of the series with a well directed short delivery.

The English openers, Cook and Trott, are making their way out to the middle. Cook will take the strike first up. Taylor will start the proceedings with the ball. There are three slips and a gully in place
Shai Hope gets his cap from the West Indian legend, Sir Clive Lloyd. His team-mates congratulate him after he puts it on.

Ramdin: 'We would have batted first as well. We will look to exploit the little bit of moisture in the first hour of play. The spinners might come into play later on as the pitch looks dry. Jerome Taylor comes in for Kemar Roach, Veerasammy Permaul for Devendra Bishoo and Shai Hope replaces Devon Smith. They (Taylor and Holder) are fully fit and with the new ball in hand, Taylor can hopefully take wickets early on. It's good to have the support here, it will be a great day with a full crowd in.'

Cook: 'We are going to bat first. It looks quite dry to me. We are unchanged for this game. Stokes is fine and is ready to go here. We are happy to see so much support here as well. We would want to end on a high and get the series win. We would ideally want to put a big total on the board here. It might swing a little in the first hour and we hopefully can tackle it well.'

Pitch Report: 'It looks very, very flat. It looks very dry as well. There is a bit of grass rolled in, but not much. The pitch will definitely have more bounce than the last game, but it is without a doubt a batsman's pitch. Win the toss and bat first here.'

Surprise, Surprise! Jason Holder has been included in the playing XI. Looks like he has recovered from his injury. West Indies have made 3 changes - Jerome Taylor, Shai Hope and Veerasammy Permaul replace Kemar Roach, Devon Smith and Devendra Bishoo. England are unchanged for this game.
Teams:

West Indies (Playing XI): Kraigg Brathwaite, Shai Hope, Darren Bravo, Marlon Samuels, Shivnarine Chanderpaul, Jermaine Blackwood, Denesh Ramdin(w/c), Jason Holder, Jerome Taylor, Shannon Gabriel, Veerasammy Permaul
England (Playing XI): Alastair Cook(c), Jonathan Trott, Gary Ballance, Ian Bell, Joe Root, Moeen Ali, Jos Buttler(w), Ben Stokes, Chris Jordan, Stuart Broad, James Anderson
England have won the toss and have opted to bat

England though have looked more solid than the West Indies. Their bowling have been better and with Cook and Ballance getting the runs in the final innings, their batting order looks more solid now. With Joe Root batting like he is, England will be the more confident side going into this game. Expect them to field an unchanged XI too.

On the last day, Holder was stretchered off the field after he twisted his ankle in his final delivery stride. His chances of making a recovery in time to play this Test are bleak and Shannon Gabriel will probably hold on to his place in his absence. With Devendra Bishoo too carrying a niggle, Veerasamy Permaul might get a game in.

Apart from the batting collapse on the final day, West Indies batting line-up have done well so far. With four centurions in two Tests, the West Indian batters have showcased the grit to fight it out. However, it is the bowling line-up that will be their main worry. Even though West Indies will be boosted by the return of Jerome Taylor, Jason Holder's absence might hurt their chances of making a comeback in the series.

Hello and a very warm welcome to the third and final Test match between West Indies and England. The series is nicely poised for both the teams. Even though England are 1-0 up, West Indies have the firepower to end the series on equal footing. On the other hand, they will be wary of this English side, who showed us that a single session can effectively win you the game.

A poor final day with the bat from the West Indies saw England take a 1-0 lead in the 3-match series. James Anderson was the hero for England as he was involved in all the six wickets that fell in the first session of the day. England are chasing their first away series win since 2012, where they defeated India.

Preview

Despite matching up evenly in nine of the ten playing days so far, West Indies head into the final Test at Bridgetown, Barbados one-nil down and staring at another Test series loss. England on the other hand, buoyed by James Anderson's final day heroics in Grenada, are on the cusp of their first away series win since India in 2012 as they prepare for a gruelling summer of cricket at home that culminates with the all-important Ashes.

While the hosts will bank on the historically lively surface at the Kensington Oval, once a fortress for them, to help turn positive performances into meaningful results, England have the added incentive of sealing a series win that eluded them the last time they toured the Caribbean in 2009.

Start date: May 1, 2015

Venue: Kensington Oval, Barbados

Weather: Mostly Sunny with a 20% chance of rain on the opening day

Team News:

West Indies

Contrary to popular expectation, West Indies' batting has held its own against a formidable England attack. With as many as four centurions in two Tests - Jermaine Blackwood, Jason Holder, Marlon Samuels and Kraigg Brathwaite - the hosts have ticked most boxes on the batting front. The team management, however, will be sweating on the fitness of key bowlers Jerome Taylor and Holder. Taylor, who missed the second Test due to injury, is expected to return, but in the event of Holder failing to adequately recover from his injury sustained in Grenada, Shannon Gabriel will hold on to his place. Devendra Bishoo, who is carrying a niggle may be replaced by Veerasamy Permaul for the lone spinner's role.

Probable XI: 1 Kraigg Brathwaite, 2 Devon Smith, 3 Darren Bravo, 4 Marlon Samuels, 5 Shivnarine Chanderpaul 6 Jermaine Blackwood, 7 Denesh Ramdin(capt/wk), 8 Jason Holder/Jerome Taylor, 9 Kemar Roach, 10 Devendra Bishoo/ Veerasamy Permaul, 11 Shannon Gabriel

England

England, who are scheduled to play many Tests in the next 12 months, will have player workload management at the top of their agenda. But, with an away series win at stake, possibilities of sweeping changes to the side appear minimal unless enforced. A fifty in the last Test may just have given Jonathan Trott another Test cap while Moeen Ali is likely to retain his place as England look to beef up their batting, which would keep James Tredwell out for a second consecutive Test despite putting in an impressive performance in Antigua.

Probable XI: 1 Alastair Cook (capt), 2 Jonathan Trott, 3 Gary Ballance, 4 Ian Bell, 5 Joe Root, 6 Moeen Ali/James Tredwell, 7 Ben Stokes, 8 Jos Butler (wk), 9 Chris Jordan, 10 Stuart Broad, 11 James Anderson

Statistics:

- Shivnarine Chanderpaul needs 71 runs to overtake Brian Lara as the leading run-scorer for West Indies in Test cricket.

- With 324 runs in three innings at a staggering average of 162, Joe Root tops the batting charts in the series.

Quotes:

"He's the glue that holds the England Team together"

- Ben Stokes received rich praise from West Indies coach Phil Simmons

"I still feel there's a lot more of my batting to come"

- Moeen Ali believes he hasn't justified his batting talent in the long format
Teams:

West Indies (From): Kraigg Brathwaite, Devon Smith, Darren Bravo, Marlon Samuels, Shivnarine Chanderpaul, Jermaine Blackwood, Denesh Ramdin(c/w), Jason Holder, Jerome Taylor, Veerasammy Permaul, Shannon Gabriel, Kemar Roach, Shai Hope, Carlos Brathwaite

England (From): Alastair Cook(c), Jonathan Trott, Gary Ballance, Ian Bell, Joe Root, Moeen Ali, Jos Buttler(w), Ben Stokes, Chris Jordan, Stuart Broad, James Anderson, Adam Lyth, Jonathan Bairstow, Liam Plunkett, Mark Wood, Adil Rashid, James Tredwell
